importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date the lawsuit was filed, signaling a critical moment in the dispute over the swearing-in of Representative Adelita Grijalva.
The date when Adelita Grijalva won her election as a member of Congress, establishing the legal and constitutional basis for her appointment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 28-day period between Grijalva’s election and the filing of the lawsuit, during which no formal swearing-in occurred, highlighting the duration of the delay and raising constitutional questions.

keyTakeAways: The U.S. Constitution requires elected members of Congress to be sworn in, regardless of Speaker’s discretion.
Speaker Mike Johnson claims to be following a precedent set by Nancy Pelosi, delaying swearing-in of newly elected representative Adelita Grijalva.

Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes filed a federal lawsuit alleging that Johnson’s refusal to administer the oath violates constitutional principles and harms the elected representative and constituents.
The lawsuit asserts that the Speaker has no constitutional authority to deny seating of a duly elected member.
Johnson denies the lawsuit, calling it a public relations effort and claims he is following precedent and not blocking a petition over Epstein records or budget negotiations.
Grijalva has expressed a desire to meet with Johnson to resolve the standoff and avoid further public conflict.
The legal action seeks a court order allowing a qualified individual to administer the oath to Grijalva if Johnson refuses.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Arizona Representative Adelita Grijalva, claiming that the Constitution mandates the seating of duly elected members and that Johnson’s delay violates constitutional principles. Johnson justifies his refusal by citing precedent from former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arguing he will administer the oath when the House returns to session. The lawsuit contends that the Speaker has no constitutional authority to delay swearing-in, especially since he does not dispute Grijalva’s qualifications or election, and that such a delay harms both her ability to serve and the interests of Arizona constituents. It also alleges Johnson is using the delay to influence budget negotiations and a petition over Jeffrey Epstein records. Grijalva has expressed a desire to meet with Johnson to resolve the issue, while the lawsuit seeks a court order allowing a qualified officer to administer the oath if Johnson refuses.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear In Democrats’ Newest Congresswoman
